private-volunteer.prompt: I'd like to volunteer as a Budget Delegate
private-volunteer.attribution: Budget Delegates will meet 6 - 8 times from December through June‚Äã to evaluate project ideas, work with city staff to research the projects and will receive training and support to develop proposals for the ballot.

content: Already submitted an idea? There are many more ways to get involved in participatory budgeting:

Volunteers will be recruited to serve as Budget Delegates. During the Proposal Development phase of the process, these volunteer Budget Delegates will work the community and staff of relevant city of Durham departments to develop ideas into budget proposals. They will receive training and support from Durham PB Implementation Staff to do so. In addition to supporting the Budget Delegates, Durham PB Implementation staff will also serve to facilitate communication so that projects can be developed in a timely manner.

Each ward will have a neighborhood assembly and other, informal idea collection events, to encourage widespread participation. Visit www.pbdurham.org for upcoming assembly dates, times, and locations.
Find us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!
Please contact Robin Baker, Budget Engagement Coordinator for Participatory Budgeting Durham, by email at pbdurham@durhamnc.gov or phone at 984-227-3395.
<iframe id='guidelines-video' src='https://player.vimeo.com/video/162743651?color=ff9933&byline=0' width='100%' frameborder='0' webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>
Residents and students of Durham age 13 and older can generate initial project ideas at idea collection assemblies, "pop-up" events, and online at pbdurham.org.
Idea Collection is open from November 1st - December 21st.
To review all guidelines for the process please read the PB Rulebook (link to come).
Put your money where your ideas are!
Durham Participatory Budgeting is a democratic process in which community members from all three City Council wards are directly deciding how to spend $2.4 million ($800,000 per ward).

From November 2018 to March 2019, volunteer budget delegates will work to develop these initial ideas into full project proposals. Durham residents will be able to vote in May 2019 to determine the winning projects.

"One-time projects" are projects with one-time expenditures that address a community need. Projects can be built on City, Durham Housing Authority, and private land, upon donation. "One-time projects" may include physical infrastructure, technological improvements, and community enhancements. Examples of "one-time projects" include park improvements, computers for a community center, bus shelters, and bike-lanes. "One-time projects" may have some sort of associated operating cost. However, they do not require the City to hire additional staff.
For more information on participatory budgeting in Durham, Click here!
For information on the nationwide movement for PB, visit the website of the Participatory Budgeting Project.
